Executive Summary for Calpine king City Cogen RMP
This document represents the updated and revised Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the Calpine King City Cogen, LLC (CKCC) located in King City, California. This document has been prepared in order to address the following issues:
Acknowledge the continued operation of an existing source with processes subject to the RMP regulations and requirements. (EPA RMP Facility ID# 1000-0016-4877)
CKCC uses anhydrous ammonia and stores greater than 20,000 lbs of anhydrous ammonia making the site subject to both the California Accidental Release Program (CalARP) and the Federal RMP Program under 40 CFR 68. The site is subject to the OSHA and EPA Process Safety Management Regulations. The site has been determined to be a Program Level 3 facility.
The RMP addresses the Program 3 requirements of CalARP as adopted by the State of California as outlined in California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 19. These requirements build upon the provisions of the ?general duty clause? of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990, and the federal RMP Program 3 requirements in 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 68, which require the following activities of all facilities which produce, process, store, or handle listed substances:
identify hazards
design and maintain a safe facility
prevent releases
minimize the consequences of releases.
The required approach to accomplishing the above, pursuant to the CalARP and Federal RMP regulations, is to have a documented RMP, which outlines the steps and procedures a facility will take to prevent and mitigate accidental releases. 
Pursuant to CCR Title 19, Section 2745.3, the following summary is given:
This RMP applies to the CKCC facility located at:
750 Metz Road
King City, CA.  93930
Latitude: 360 13? 30?, Longitude -1210 7? 38?

Facility Description and Regulated Substances
The CKCC facility is a 111-megawatt (MW) (nominal output) natural-gas-fired combined cycle power plant. Electrici

ty generated by CKCC is sold to Pacific Gas and Electric Company. In addition to the sale of electricity, CKCC produces and sells thermal energy to a thermal host, Gilroy Foods, an affiliate of Conagra Foods, Inc., under a long-term contract coterminous with the power sales agreement.
The site is located at 750 Metz Rd., near the intersection of Airport Drive, on the northeast side of King City, CA.(T20S, R8E, S5, NW1/4)
Substance Used/Stored:	Anhydrous Ammonia (CAS# 7664-41-7)
				12,000 gallon tank*
				(* maximum allowed storage per administrative policy is 10,440 gals.)

Facility SIC Code: 4911	Facility NAICS Code: 221112
The accidental release prevention and emergency action policies at the facility are delineated in Sections 4.0 and 14.0 respectively. A brief description of the prevention and emergency action policies is as follows.
Accident Prevention Program Policies and Elements
The accident prevention program is implemented through an established set of policies and programs including, but not limited to, the following:
Inspection and maintenance program for all system equipment.
Monitoring of employee and contractor use of the system.
Contractor Safety Program
Emergency Action  Plan
Lockout/Tagout Procedures and Program
Hot Work Permit Program
Confined Space Entry Program
Employee Safety Training Program
Management of Change Program
Employee Participation Program
Pre-startup Review Program
Compilation of substance information (MSDS)
Incident investigation procedures
Periodic compliance audits.
Compliance with all applicable laws, ordinances, and regulations.

Integral parts of the prevention program are the following plans:
Emergency Action Plan - Hazardous Materials Business Plan ? Injury and Illness Prevention Plan ? Spill Containment Control and Countermeasure Plan ? Hazardous Waste Storage and Handling Procedures ? Hazard Communication Program ? Fire Protection and Prevention Procedures ? Hearing Conservation Program ? Respi

ratory Conservation Program ? Electrical Safety Program ? Proposition 65 Compliance Program ? Forklift and Industrial Truck Program ? Welding, Cutting, and Brazing Safety Program ? Personal Protective Equipment ? Risk Management Program ? Chemical Hygiene.
These plans are kept on site, for inspection during normal business hours.
Emergency Action Policies and Elements
The emergency action program is implemented through an established set of policies and programs including, but not limited to, the following:
Establishment of criteria defining an emergency
Staff training and responsibility assignments
Emergency notification procedures (on and off-site)
Evacuation procedures
Written emergency action  procedures
Coordination of emergency action with local authorities
Incident investigation and follow-up procedures
The general accidental release prevention program is comprised of the following elements:
Proper maintenance of all system equipment.
Proper operation of all system equipment.
Internal operating policies with respect to ammonia tank capacity.
Comprehensive personnel training.
A written emergency action plan.
A written hazardous materials management plan.
Documented safety procedures for employees and contractors.
Inclusion of ammonia specific health, safety, and response data in the RMP.
The project is an existing source and has not experienced an accidental release of ammonia or any other hazardous substance in the last 5 years.
The emergency action plan and procedures (EAP) for CKCC are similar in scope and detail to the EAP for similar Calpine power generation facilities (See section 14.0 and Appendix H). The Monterey County and/or King City Fire Departments will be the first responders in an ammonia emergency. CKCC personnel will perform "awareness" duties only, which simply means that once the ammonia spill or release is discovered, CKCC personnel will make the proper notifications and set the emergency procedures in motion. The fire

departments will handle spill/release response and mitigation. In the event of a major release, CKCC may join forces with the fire departments and State/County OES personnel in a "unified command effort" until the emergency has been mitigated.
Chemical Specific Prevention Elements
Chemical specific prevention measures are summarized as follows:
Periodic inspection of ammonia tank, containment area, pumps, piping network, flow controllers, and injection grid.
Monitoring of tank and system pressures and temperatures.
Monitoring of unloading/delivery procedures.
Installation and use of ammonia detector(s) in the main tank area.
Provide all required safety and response equipment.
Provide a chemical specific training program.
Access to the CKCC facility site is controlled and fenced.
The piping and distribution network is equipped with a number of manual and automatic valves, which effectively limit the amount and duration of any accidental release. System pressures and flow rates will be monitored at the main plant control room console. Review of the P&IDs (Appendix C) indicates that there are numerous pressure, temperature, and level indicator sensors, which will be reported directly to the distributed control system (DCS) for operator confirmation and action.
Planned Changes to Improve Safety
	Presently, Calpine is operating and constructing a number of similar peaking and base loaded power generation facilities in California. Data developed from the operational experience at these facilities will be directly applied to the operation and safety aspects of the CKCC facility. Operational and safety issues identified at any Calpine facility are immediately analyzed for applicability to other operational sites. Additionally, the following will be used to identify and track safety improvements at CKCC.
Completion of the revised PHA for the CKCC facility
Required periodic updating of the PHA per the CalARP and Federal regulations
Implementation and revision t

o safety and training procedures
Continued compliance with applicable building and seismic codes

The facility will constantly strive for improved performance and reliability from all its processes. As specific process and safety improvements are identified they will be evaluated by staff for application and implementation.

Training
The facility staff, as well as Calpine corporate staff, understands that incidents involving the accidental release of listed substances can be reduced and/or eliminated by having trained operations and maintenance staff. A training program, which incorporates specific operating procedures and safe work practices, is an essential element of an effective prevention program.
The training program is comprised of the following:
Initial employee training
Periodic re-training and certification
Training provided as a result of a new equipment addition or modification 
Refresher training
Training records for each employee

Maintenance and Mechanical Integrity

The maintenance and mechanical integrity element of the plant operations procedures ensures that new and modified equipment or processes are manufactured to meet process requirements, that they are installed correctly, and subsequently maintained in safe operating condition. 
The facility?s maintenance system is contained within the plant?s computerized maintenance management system (CMMS) known as PMC and applicable maintenance manuals. The system manuals delineate such practices as:
Equipment or process inspection techniques and frequency
Preventative maintenance schedules
Maintenance requirements and procedures
History of maintenance
Process identification, model numbers, and serial numbers
Maintenance logs (who performed the maintenance, and information on the maintenance activity, etc.)
PMC contains such records as:
Written maintenance, testing, and inspection procedures and schedules.
Maintenance training.
Maintenance documentation.
Deficiency correction

procedures and documentation.

Pre-Startup Review

The facility is comprised of a variety of processes, i.e., fuel combustion, fuel handling, water treatment, chemical use, etc. Additions or modifications to these processes may be required to improve safety and operability. These modifications may require that the process safety information be revised and updated. The pre-startup review applies to additions or modifications, which require the process safety information to be updated. The facility pre-startup safety review procedure will be contained within the plant operations manuals. The review generally addresses the following issues:
Equipment designed and installed according to prevailing industry standards and specifications.
Construction per existing building and seismic codes and standards.
Adequate safety and emergency procedures are developed and implemented.
PHA performed prior to startup.
MoC procedures initiated and completed.
Training of affected employees initiated and completed.
Whenever changes in affected processes are identified or planned, they must be evaluated as to the need for a pre-startup safety review. This assessment is undertaken in conjunction with the MoC review. Additionally, a pre-startup safety review will be performed in conjunction with the MoC review when the proposed change requires modifications to the safety procedures.

Compliance Audits

An essential element of the RMP program is the use of periodic compliance audits to assess the effectiveness of the written plan. Compliance audits under the federal and state RMP regulations must be conducted, at a minimum of once every three years. The periodic compliance audit addresses the following:
Implementation and comprehension of the current plan elements.
Are plan revisions required.
Does the plan adequately address all required RMP elements.
Effectiveness of the current plan.
Level of employee involvement.
Management commitment to plan provisions.
The audit

team is typically comprised of people knowledgeable of the process. The results of the compliance audit are communicated to all staff levels subsequent to completion of the audit.
Incident Investigation
Thorough investigation of ?incidents? (any occurrence that results in or could result in catastrophic releases of anhydrous ammonia) or ?near misses? (any situation where conditions existed under which an incident could have occurred, but did not) is another essential element of the RMP program. Incident investigations typically yield perspectives on equipment or process safety that are not normally apparent to plant operations and maintenance staff, such as:
Incident ?causes? outside of the PHA scope.
Was the facility response appropriate?
Did the EAP function as designed?
Did the EAP and RMP provide the necessary level of protection with respect to the offsite impacts?
What changes need to be made to the RMP and EAP to ensure an appropriate response in the future?
Incident investigations pursuant to this RMP will be specific to the anhydrous ammonia process system. The following data is typically gathered by the incident investigation team subsequent to the incident:
Date and time of the ?incident? or ?near miss?
Timeliness of incident report to the responding agency
Timeliness of public awareness and/or evacuation measures
Description of the incident or ?near miss?
An evaluation of the events that resulted in the incident or ?near miss?
Recommendations to prevent future occurrences of the incident
The incident investigation policy is delineated in the safety procedures. The investigation results, including the implementation of all recommendations, will be reviewed with facility staff whose job responsibilities are relevant to the findings. Copies of the investigation reports will be maintained on site for a minimum of five years, and will be used during the periodic PHA re-evaluations.

Employee Participation

The facility must rely upon the op

erational expertise and training of its employees (including contractors) at all levels and disciplines to ensure safe operations. Operational safety is achieved by a constant exchange of information with employees to ensure consideration of their knowledge and experience in all applicable areas of the prevention program. The facility will implement procedures regarding employee participation in the prevention program elements, the hazard assessment, and emergency action program. The written employee participation plan and facility policies will ensure that:
Employees at all staff levels are participants in the development and implementation of PHAs. 
Employees at all staff levels are participants in the development of the prevention program elements, the hazard assessment, and the emergency action program.
Employees at all staff levels are given access to PHA data, EAP data, offsite consequence data, plan implementation data, etc.
Management of Change

Operational, safety, and environmental issues must be addressed whenever a change occurs at a facility, which involves an affected process or substance. Quite often a change made in one aspect of the process may affect other parts of the process due to facility system integration. Such changes must be reviewed prior to initiation, to ensure that they do not compromise the operational safety and integrity of the process, and to minimize adverse effects to worker safety and public health. The facility MoC procedures will be used to evaluate all changes to the following types of systems:
Process chemicals (delivery, storage, handling)
Control technology systems (operation rates, chemicals used, by-products or wastes produced)
Equipment design and construction
Operations and maintenance procedures
Other changes to facility equipment or processes
Contractor Safety and Hot Work Program

Acknowledgement and control of open and/or enclosed ignition sources such as welding equipment, cutting and brazing torches,

etc., is essential for the protection of workers and the prevention of accidental releases of listed substances. Facility staff, as well as contractor staff, must be aware of such sources and hazards, and must take the proper safety precautions during the timeframe that such work is being undertaken. The facility will develop a Hot Work Permit program, which requires that employees complete the necessary work order and notification forms certifying that the applicable portions of the fire prevention and protection plan requirements are implemented prior to the start of hot work operations.
Hot Work Permits will be required for all types of open or enclosed ignition sources such as grinding, burning, welding, and brazing. Work performed on or near affected processes, or in areas not approved for cutting and welding pursuant to the fire prevention plan must also have a Hot Work permit. The Hot Work Permit is voided when the use of the ignition source results in a hazardous situation, when conditions of its issuance change, or when the work task requiring the Hot Work permit has been inactive for more than a pre-determined time period appropriate for the job task.

The facility will utilize outside contractors to augment the existing workforce both on a regular basis, as well as during periods of maintenance outages, overhauls and construction. Contractors must comply with the requirements of the Contractor Safety Program. The facility staff has the primary responsibility for ensuring on-site safety and therefore must take the appropriate measures to ensure that all contractors are trained and understand the site specific safety procedures and programs, including, but not limited to:
Work practices, equipment and process knowledge, and safety procedures necessary to perform the job.
Equipment and process hazards identified for the task or job.
Emergency action procedures and knowledge of safety equipment use.
Knowledge of safe work practices.
Contractors also

have a responsibility to inform the facility staff of any specialized hazards which may be introduced while performing their work.

Release Scenario Data
The worst-case release scenario is the failure of the anhydrous ammonia storage tank with full containment. This scenario results in the release of approximately 52200 pounds of ammonia. Ammonia concentrations reach fence line exposures on the order of 15,000 ppm. The zone of impact, defined as the distance to the ammonia Te value, is 3950m, and covers an approximate area of 4.734 sq.miles, with an affected population per Landview VI of approximately 13,000 individuals (2000 census data adjusted for annual population growth of 3.2%).
The alternate-case release scenario is the failure of the anhydrous ammonia loading hose with no containment. This scenario results in the release of approximately 75 pounds of ammonia. Ammonia concentrations reach fence line exposures on the order of 70 ppm. There is NO zone of impact for this scenario, as the Te value of 201 ppm is not reached or exceeded at any onsite or offsite location. Onsite staff would be subject to ammonia concentrations below the Te value for this scenario.
